content:
The "Ricky Ray Hemophilia Relief Fund Act of 1998" includes provisions for a relief fund for individuals with blood-clotting disorders and HIV, compassionate payments, determination and payment processes, limitations on rights transfer and petitions, time limitations, and definitions. Additionally, it addresses the treatment of private settlement payments in hemophilia-clotting-factor suits under the Medicaid and SSI programs. Sec. 201 addresses the treatment of private settlement payments in hemophilia-clotting-factor suits under the Medicaid and SSI programs. Establishment of the "Ricky Ray Hemophilia Relief Fund" in the Treasury of the United States to be administered by the Secretary of the Treasury. Amounts in the Fund to be invested in accordance with section 9702 of title 31, United States Code. Fund availability only for disbursement by the Secretary of Health and Human Services under section 103. Fund termination after a 5-year period from the enactment of the Act, with remaining amounts to be liquidated and deposited back. The Ricky Ray Hemophilia Relief Fund will be liquidated after 5 years, with remaining funds deposited in the Treasury's miscellaneous receipts account. $750 million is authorized for the Fund. SEC. 102. COMPASSIONATE PAYMENT FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH BLOOD-CLOTTING DISORDERS AND HIV. The Secretary will make a $100,000 payment from the Fund to individuals with HIV who have a blood-clotting disorder and were treated with antihemophilic factor between July 1, 1982, and December 31, 1987, or are spouses of individuals meeting these criteria. The individual can receive a $100,000 payment from the Fund if they have HIV and were treated with antihemophilic factor between July 1, 1982, and December 31, 1987, or are spouses of individuals meeting these criteria. To qualify, the individual must submit medical documentation of HIV infection, file a petition with the Secretary, and meet the requirements of this title as determined by the Secretary. SEC. 103. DETERMINATION AND PAYMENT. The Secretary of Health and Human Services establishes filing procedures for individuals to submit petitions for payment under this title, requiring written medical documentation of a blood-clotting disorder. The Secretary determines if each petition meets the requirements and pays from the Fund in order received, if sufficient amounts are available. Payments in case of deceased individuals under section 102(a) are distributed as follows: to the surviving spouse if alive, equally among living children if no surviving spouse, and equally among living parents if no spouse or children. If an individual eligible for payment under section 102(a) dies before filing a petition, a survivor may file on their behalf. Definitions include spouse as a lawful partner at the time of death, and child as a recognized natural offspring. If no surviving spouse, children, or parents, the payment reverts back to the Fund. The Act allows for payments to be made to survivors of eligible individuals who have passed away. The term "child" includes recognized natural, stepchildren in a parent-child relationship, and adopted children. The term "parent" includes fathers and mothers through adoption. The Secretary must make a determination on a petition within 120 days of filing. The Act emphasizes the humanitarian nature of the payments. The Act emphasizes the humanitarian nature of payments made to survivors of eligible individuals who have passed away due to HIV infection from treatment with antihemophilic factor between July 1, 1982, and December 31, 1987. Payments under this Act are in full satisfaction of any claims against the United States or its agents. Administrative costs cannot be paid from the Fund, and the Secretary's duties under this section end when the Fund terminates. Payments under this section are treated as damages for tax purposes, not counted as income for determining eligibility for certain benefits, and are not subject to reimbursement or reduction of benefits. The Secretary may issue regulations for this title and establish procedures within 120 days of enactment. SEC. 104. LIMITATION ON TRANSFER OF RIGHTS AND NUMBER OF PETITIONS. Any right under this title shall not be assignable or transferable. With respect to each individual described in section 102(a), the Secretary may not make payment for more than one petition. SEC. 105. TIME LIMITATION. The Secretary may not make any payment for a petition filed under this title after 3 years from the enactment of this Act. SEC. 106. CERTAIN CLAIMS NOT AFFECTED BY PAYMENT. SEC. 106. A payment under section 103(c)(1) does not count as compensation or reimbursement for imposing liability on the recipient to repay insurance or worker's compensation. It also does not affect any claims against insurance carriers or persons for worker's compensation. SEC. 107. Agents cannot receive more than 5% of the payment under this title for services rendered, with a fine of up to $50,000 for violations. SEC. 108. Definitions. TITLE II--TREATMENT OF CERTAIN PAYMENTS IN HEMOPHILIA-CLOTTING-FACTOR SUIT UNDER THE SSI PROGRAM. Definitions: AIDS - acquired immune deficiency syndrome, Fund - Ricky Ray Hemophilia Relief Fund, HIV - human immunodeficiency virus, Secretary - Secretary of Health and Human Services. Private payments from specific settlements or releases are not considered income or resources for determining eligibility for medical assistance or supplemental security income benefits under certain provisions of the Social Security Act. These payments include those from the Susan Walker v. Bayer Corporation settlement and releases in related cases. Private payments from specific settlements or releases, such as the Susan Walker v. Bayer Corporation settlement, are not considered income or resources for determining eligibility for medical assistance or supplemental security income benefits under certain provisions of the Social Security Act. The settlement must be signed by all affected parties within a specified timeframe. Government payments from the Fund established under section 101 of this Act are not considered income or resources for determining eligibility for supplemental security income benefits under the Social Security Act.
